Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The buddhist friend asks to discuss a recent sermon they attended.
Story: The phone pressed against my ear, I listened as another prospect asked about the technical details of our new service. My script only skimmed the surface, and I could hear the skepticism in their voice. My supervisor expected me to handle objections smoothly, to keep the call moving, to close the sale. I felt the pressure to perform, to be persuasive, to not let the conversation slip away. Yet, my mind kept drifting to the text from my Buddhist friend, inviting me to discuss the sermon we’d heard last night about mindfulness and right speech. I was supposed to be present, to reflect, to engage in honest, thoughtful conversation about the Dharma. But here I was, reciting half-truths, dodging questions, my words feeling hollow. The phone rang again. My friend’s message blinked on my screen. I felt torn, my heart pulled between the demands of my job and the call to spiritual integrity. I stared at the blinking cursor, caught between answering the next call and responding to my friend, unsure which voice to honor.
